top_comment.text:
Brian, I need a new "G.T.H." hat to take when we go out.  What kind is that 
one you have?  Any issues with ventilation with it? ﻿
top_comment.author: Kallapryy

comments.text:
I will be looking for a Jacaru then Sir!  Thank you very much!  I think it 
will make a fine G.T.H. hat for sailing!  Thanks!
comments.author: Kallapryy

comments.text:
+Kallapryy So my hat is a "Jacaru" I bought in Australia.  Brady's is a 
one-off he bought at the Darwin Market made from old road-train canvas or 
something crazy like that. Not much ventilation but it definitely keeps you 
cooler and the sun off your head\shoulders. Hope that helps!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

top_comment.text:
Do you guys ever get concerned about security on some of these adventures? 
 Pearl farms, local military and police, armed security approaching your 
boat.  Language barriers...anything ever raise the hair on the back of your 
neck?   Ever concerned about Pirates and security for Delos when your off 
diving a few miles away??  Just wondering...﻿
top_comment.author: JoJo Kadilihopper

comments.text:
British Navy, Royal Navy, give me a fucken break, even an idiot like you 
figured out what I was saying!!!
comments.author: JoJo Kadilihopper

comments.text:
+JoJo Kadilihopper British Navy? What is that? It's the *Royal Navy*. 
Google is your friend not your enemy, don't be afraid to use it. :)
comments.author: knut761

comments.text:
+JoJo Kadilihopper Yea, it does pay to be aware.  We constantly monitor 
noonsite.com and the US Navy intel reports on the areas before we visit.  
They have a pretty sweet forecast site that takes things into account such 
as weather and types of boats in operation in the area.  sometimes bad 
weather can really be in our favor.  Anyway, it can change from season to 
season and month to month so we will just have to see when we get a little 
closer!  Fair Winds- Brian SV Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
I understand, its certain parts of the world tend to be a little more risky 
then others and you guys are getting into those area's.  Somalia is a 
concern but I do believe navy vessels are patrolling the area's.  The 
pirates have been quiet at least I haven't heard much.  The trip to Cape 
town should be given a wide berth in "certain" area's is all I am saying. 
 I think the US navy and British Navy and others patrol the area, tankers 
have been taken and small pleasure craft.  Are you going to chart a course 
through that area or give it a very wide berth?
comments.author: JoJo Kadilihopper

comments.text:
+JoJo Kadilihopper Yes, it does cross our minds a lot and we do take a 
number of precautions.  We've never felt threatened by any of the people 
we've come across when we're out cruising though.  We have felt strange in 
a few ports and cities though, like Sorong (next video in the series).  At 
the end of the day though you can't let the boat own you. If we worried too 
much we'd never leave Delos and miss out on a whole lot!  Fair Winds- Brian 
SV Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

top_comment.text:
one question :
Who's stay on the boat when you all off to the shore ?
I mean is it safe to leaved it unguarded at the spot you're anchoring ?
Because seems you all went together most of the time.﻿
top_comment.author: Sparta Otano

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos
yeah I couldn't agree more.
even when you all were on the boat sh** still happened like in Ambon right.
just keep safe then..
comments.author: Sparta Otano

comments.text:
+Sparta Otano In this particular case we made friends with the local 
security guards that were patrolling the area in their boat, so we felt 
safe.  In places where we don't feel safe we always try to leave someone on 
board but sometimes it's just not possible.  At the end of the day you 
can't let the boat "own" you though, and if something is going to happen 
you just have to roll with it and do your best.  Fair Winds, Brian S/V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

top_comment.text:
Wow!! You are so lucky to have visited such a sacred spot. Thankyou for 
respecting there wishes and there culture. 
Beautiful.
One Life, One Search,
Peace Out,
Shane﻿
top_comment.author: Tattered Passport

comments.text:
+SV Delos Crew Love the cruise watched the whole thing at least 7 times now 
. I loved the the second the aborigines stopped dancing in unison the 
moment their music stopped.Great narrating, Great Videos. Phebes gives me a 
body rush when she starts singing. Great pipes. Tell me though , how does 
one go from burger flipping, to cruising the world in a multi million 
dollar sailing yacht? Oh yeah, I'm heading out there in summer of 16.Hope 
to bump into you and your crew. Now what are the chances of that?
comments.author: robert orzech

comments.text:
Yes, we feel very lucky to have shared in this experience as well.  Such 
nice people to spend their time with us showing crazy foreigners around.  
Fair Winds, and thanks for watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

top_comment.text:
Nice Amel Super Maramu. It's a very expensive boat. You must be independent 
wealthy to own a boat like this, and be at sea for 6 years.﻿
top_comment.author: ebiros2

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Thank you I did check out your blog. You really thought out 
everything well. I plan to go cruising for few years when I retire on a 
sailing catamaran, and making plans for it. Your blog was very inspiring.
comments.author: ebiros2

comments.text:
Wealthy in life, but not really money :)  If you're interested in how we 
afford the trip check out these blog posts if you have a few minutes:  
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-1by-brian.html 
and 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-2-by-brian.html

Thanks for watching!
Brian
S\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

top_comment.text:
Hi Brian and crew. This is by far my favorite channel and after watching 
all your videos at least twice I've made it a habit to check almost daily 
for the next video to be posted. Since getting my first sailboat this 
summer as a gift (a Hobie 16 Catamaran), I have become instantly hooked and 
have begun planning my liveaboard sailing adventure from the Gulf of Mexico 
to the Caribbean through Panama into South Pacific. I'm trying to soak in 
as much information about sailing as I can get my hands on. Can you please 
give me some suggestions on books about sailing that you recommend? Also, 
what are some of your favorite youtube sailing channels? Thanks for the 
info and the hours of entertainment you've provided with your videos. - 
Cheers!﻿
top_comment.author: Coulson Mullen

comments.text:
+Mark M Hey Mark- I agree with you and found The Voyager's Handbook to be 
pretty awesome for getting my head wrapped around cruising.  Strangely 
enough I got another comment from someone after recommending this book and 
do believe that this is Delos, although with the previous owner.  I bought 
her in 2008.....
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
WhiteSpotPirates is another great channel that I recently found about a 
solo female sailor who bought an aged boat that has a new issue every time 
it leaves the marina. She's a very likable 20 something German who is 
determined to solo sail the globe. If you have other similar channels, 
please let me know.
comments.author: Coulson Mullen

comments.text:
+Mark M That book has been on my list for a while. With your 
recommendation, I just Amazoned it. I'm glad you made mention of the 2nd 
edition [2006]. Anxious to hear what Brian says, you're right, quite a 
coincidence if it's not the same vessel. However, I believe that was a 
couple of years before he was captain. Still interesting nonetheless. 
Thanks Mark, Cheers!
comments.author: Coulson Mullen

comments.text:
If you think you might some day want to live aboard and go cruising a great 
book is The Voyager's Handbook by Beth Leonard. There is also a reference 
on page 9 in the 2nd edition to a boat called Delos which happens to be a 
53ft Amel Ketch. I would love to here from Brian or one of the other guys 
on Delos if there is any correlation. Seems like quite a coincidence ;). 
regardless Its a great read that leads you through each step in choosing, 
planning, and following a voyager's life.
comments.author: Mark M

comments.text:
+Eric Lewis Thanks Eric. Chapman was my 1st book on sailing. I already have 
Don Casey's Manual, but haven't started it yet because it seems like it's 
going to be a real grid to read. After your recommendation I just looked at 
Sail Power and looks interesting for sure. I will get it and check it out. 
Cheers!
comments.author: Coulson Mullen

comments.text:
Chapman Piloting, Sail Power by Wallace Ross, and Don Casey's Complete 
Illustrated Sailboat Maintenance Manual.
comments.author: Eric Lewis

captions.text:
"So we're just coming from the
South-East part of Misool,

and we found this sweet little
cut-through, that comes through
northern part on the eastern
side

and there's heaps of rock
islands everywhere!

The cliffs go straight down, on
both sides, down to over 30 or
40 meters.

But we're just being safe, and
doing depth soundings

and talking on the radio making
sure we don't hit anything, cos
it's not really chartered right
here

We're gonna find a sweet
anchorage by a beach, and
hopefully explore
some caves wall art!"
We do this pretty often on Delos

It's one of the benefits of
having a few more people on
board in a very fast dingy.

We would Delos through holes in
the limestone cliffs.

We were headed West towards
Tomolol Bay, where we hoped to
find a cave we'd heard about.

The entire bay was full of
Pearl Farms!

They stretched for miles and
miles completely blocking our
way.

We were forced to anchor a few
miles further out than we
hoped.

At least we had the hook set
before this squall hit and
ruined the vis.

"Are you excited Josje-Rama?"
"We're goin to the caves!"

"CAVES! Dingy adventure, Delos
sytle"

"It's gonna be a long one hour
dingy ride.. but.. let's do it!"

Just after anchoring we were
approached by two boats full of
armed men.

We made friends and asked them
aboard for coffee,

but they'd have to leave their
assault rifles behind.

It was their job to guard the
pearl farm from thieves and
dynamite fisherman.

They said they often shot at
suspicious boats in the night
but we'd be very safe here.

They even offered to guard
Delos for us.

We hitched a ride to their
village in search of fruit and
veggies.

All they had to offer was
cigarettes and Soppee

which is Indonesia's version of
Moonshine

made from distilled Palm Wine.
It tastes terrible but is very
potent!

Our new friends told us to keep
heading West. Towards the end
of the bay we'd find a big
platform..

and they might be able to help
us find the cave we were
searching for.

"We have a huge welcoming
party!"
The platform was pretty intense.

We were greeted by hundreds of
pearl farm workers and more
security.

They weren't quite sure what to
do with us so we just waited
and smiled.

Pretty soon everyone had their
phones out and it was like the
Indonesian
Pearl Farm Worker Paparazzi!

I don't think they get many
foreign guests here!

(laughing)
(people cheering)
"WOOO!"
(Singing)
(laughing)

Some people take the bus to
work,

others a dual outboard
fiberglass boat.

After a while we were escorted
into the security office.

He asked where we were from
and jotted down a few details.

His slight smile gave em away
though.

I had a feeling this was just a
formality as we were the only
people in their guest book.
"Yeah, no problem"
"Nina.."

"We just signed the Visitor Log
Book..

for The Army Police Station
here at the end of Tomolol Bay.

And noe we're gonna go check
out the cave, we picked up a
pretty sweet guide!
So pretty stocked about that!"

"So to the cave we go!"
"Off to the cave!"

"No, no, no..."
"Oh, ok"

"Trying to weave our way
through the shallow coral area"

I secretly had my handheld GPS
running just to know where we
were!

It turns out we went almost
6KM inland through winding and
hidden waterways.

There's absolutely no way we
would have found this place on
our own.
Then we came around a corner..
And there it was!

And there it was!
The elusive sacred cave of
Tomolol bay!

"Luckily got security to guide
us here"
"The Army AND the local Police"

The cave was eerily quiet and
still, yet there was a tangible
presence in the air.

Our guides were acting a little
strange and only went inside
for a few moments at most.

They got across that this was
an extremely sacred site for
them.

They believed that the spirits
of their ancestors dwell in
this cave.

We were kindly asked not to
swim or explore any further

into the cave out of respect
for the spirits here.

They preferred to wait outside
the cave where they felt more
comfortable.

Respecting their wishes we cut
our visit short and didn't
spend too long.

We had high hopes of exploring
deep into the cave.

After all it had taken nearly
two days to find it.

But it's really the journey
that's the important part, not
the destination.

We had an amazing time
tracking it down and met some
fantastic people.

That's what cruising's all
about anyway.
Up Next!

We find a beautiful, secluded
island to celebrate Karin's
birthday!
And party like rock stars!

"Nina, do you get any updates on your phone at all?"
"If I get 3G.."

"Did you hear.. that actress got stabbed?"
"Who?"

"ZINGER!"
"OHHHHH!!!!!"

"You wouldn't of had any news
updates.."

(laughing)
"You fell right into though!"

title: 29. S\V Delos- The Sacred Cave Of Tomolul
